posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Some comments about your lead, Rienion...
  • Please furnish both character level AND class level on your builds.  It's hard to follow if you don't.
  • Use Bull and Emp Bull to add carrying capacity and collect bags.  Avoid allocating to STR unless a spellsword design or with "spare" points.
  • Try not to end ability levels on odd numbers whenever possible.  The modifier is usually key (except for STR where odd increments add a bit more capacity).
  • Build with the race, not against it.  Gnome's boost to CON is there to gain an advantage.  Exploit it.
  • Points allocated to CHA in a non-CHA build are wasted.
  • Wizard gets Scribe Scroll as a class feat at Wiz 1 for FREE.
  • Mobility's usefulness is only temporary.  Once Tumble reaches its highest level, Mobility will not be a factor (avoidance rather than an AC bonus).  Dodge is fine.
  • Unless anticipating being spammed by Silence consistently, you'll never use Silent Spell.  Use Lesser Dispel to remove most occurrences.  Boost Will saves with Emp Owl and wear +Will items in anticipation of encountering massed silencers.  For a spellsword, Silent Spells adds more True Strike slots but this is not a spellsword.  It will be using polymorphed forms to cause physical damage.
  • Try to take Empowered Spell no later than Wiz 7 to reap full benefits ASAP.
  • Magic staff has no weapon focus so poor choice for spellsword type action.  Choose a weapon based on magic enhancements like immunities or useful free feats (like Haste, +abilities, +regen, etc.) or for spell charges.  Going unarmed just wastes a slot. Try to avoid equipping a ranged weapon else the AoOs will increase dramatically.  You can use ranged to kite but your magic missiles and Melf arrows will do more reliable damage per attempt.  Buy wands to use for kiting and drain them out.
Here's something very similar to a gnome I've played recently that has been modified to include the Arelith leveling constraints and a few of your preferences.  Compare to your idea (which is not bad at all btw, especially by scrawling figures on paper).

If preferred, you can shift 2 starting points from CON to +1 INT (28)/+1 STR (9) for slightly better universal DC, some slots and more skillpoints but it's a trade-off and the leveling would be affected (no AS).  From my experience playing casters, CON is the most noticeable ability that impacts gameplay and spellcasting, on par with your primary ability.  Boosting it as high as possible means your spells almost never get interrupted, taunts avoidable and maximizing Fort saves avoids the worst possible scenarios from becoming a chronic problem.  For a necromancer, high CON should be automatic.  For artillery types, it can be a bit less, but not by that much because there are archer mobs waiting to kill any mage in unison.  Some are BoE rangers and others are AAs.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Yeah, you're right about the DEX.  Made some changes and forgot to correct the output.  However, the naked AC and Reflex posted is based on DEX 13 so it's a typo.

Wizard bonus feats in epic are at Wiz 23, Wiz 26, Wiz 29, Wiz 32, etc.  every 3 levels.  I think you were translating it at character level 29 instead of wizard level 29. No bonus at Wiz 25, unfortunately.  Hellball will cost you Armor Skin.

I wasn't intimating that this was intended as a spellsword, only that weapon choice would be different if it would be a spellsword because you'd be considering the attack enhancement in that case.  Basically, for a caster it doesn't matter what the weapon is, 1H or 2H, as long as the proficiency exists to equip it.  A rapier would be a 2H weapon.  There's a vanilla shortsword called Lucky One that adds ImpEvasion if you can find it.  That would be very handy to avoid many evoc spells.  But just one example, though.  No doubt Arelith has its own custom weapons and maybe even a forge of sorts. You'll only glean a property effect in native form because item props do not merge with any arcane polymorphs or possessed familiar (you must pre-buff with Haste et al. before polymorphing).

As I mentioned in another thread, traps for a caster mage help to conserve spells/day.  And they will kill in situations that spells are borderline effective.  A few stacks of deadly Negative traps will drop most dragons, constructs and elementals in their tracks.  Just be careful of standing too close to the AoE type, like deadly Electrical.  You and any party members in the active vicinity will suffer very high damage.  Traps take some practice managing and planning the best layout, but provide a valuable dimension to spellcasting, especially in limited rest situations.  Check my guide for some general tips to help make the learning process easier.

Also, one final note about the UMD level I chose.  It's not firm.  You can reduce it to whatever you like (in increments of 5) because a wiz/rog doesn't perform a hardcore scroll check.  Just assign whatever level to cover the VALUE of the item (like those monk robes I like so much).  UMD 30 will allow any item up to around 1M gold to be equipped with the associated proficiency.  That's probably overkill considering even divine wands will value at no more than around 10K gold, if that much.  So it's more to assure that class-specific gear with lots of powerful properties can be used by the mage.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Class emulation (the most common) for UMD 15 is 100K in gold value.  Add +5 or +10 to that for racial or alignment emulations (those are quite rare, though).  I'd say 15 should be enough but you know best what's floating around the server.  Make sure not to use the cost at a merchant to determine the actual item value for use by UMD because those are inflated by a set amount and (usually) dependant on an Appraise check..  My recommendation is to always keep an extra 5 or 10 skill points set aside just in case you find some godly item that supercedes your current level.  The final dump is at Level 28 so, by then, you'll need to have determined exactly the special gear you intend to equip.

As for EMA...

Only its Dodge AC stacks.  So your Shield spell adds +4 deflection, Mage Armor (Lvl 1 spell)  +1 armor and +1 dodge (the deflection AC doesn't stack with Shield's deflection nor the nat AC with Shadow Shield), Shadow Shield adds +5 nat.  Therefore, without any further AC enhancements from items and pre-buffed, EMA will provide +5 dodge, boost deflection by +1 to +5 overriding Shield, +5 dodge AC and the difference between the AC enhancement of the robes and +5.  So the most ADDITIONAL AC that EMA can offer is +1 deflection +4 armor +5 dodge = +10.  Larger armor enhancement means less benefit as does something like +5 cloak of protection.  Where EMA really shines is that all the polymorphs can cast it on-demand as the occasional arises.

Armor Skin delivers an AC boost that stacks with anything.  Other sources:  DEX AC, capped +6 over intrinsic level (per Emp Cat and any +DEX items) and Haste/Mass Haste (+4 "other"), both of which stack with anything.  The other aspect of importance is that the AS +2 AC is there permanently while the Epic spells are 1x/day.  In other words, don't rely on EMA to solve anything but for the majority of the build sequence because you won't be able to walk around fighting creatures while boosted by EMA until level 26.

If you find any weapon within the rogue or wizard weapon proficiency that provides more impact than a magic staff, use it.  If you select according to the graphic representation on-screen you'll be intentionally nerfing the potential.  But I realize that is important to some players.  It's just that we don't build according to cosmetic appearance here at the guild.
